hotspots.label: Dry Ingredients Mixed
hotspots.fact: When you mix the brown flour and white sugar together, you're combining two different materials to make something new. This is called a **mixture** — that's when you put two or more things together, but each one stays the same kind of material. Even though they look blended, the sugar and flour are still separate tiny pieces.

vocabulary.definition: When two or more materials are put together but each one stays the same kind of material.

hotspots.label: Red Liquid Ingredient
hotspots.fact: The red liquid in the KitchenAid mixer is a different state of matter than the dry ingredients. This liquid will mix with the dry ingredients to change their properties and create cake batter. When a liquid and solids combine, they create a new material with completely different properties from what you started with!

vocabulary.definition: The form something takes — like solid (hard), liquid (flows), or gas (invisible air).

hotspots.label: KitchenAid Mixer
hotspots.fact: The mixer uses a **force** called rotation to spin the beaters around and around very fast. This spinning force pushes and breaks apart the ingredients, mixing them together evenly. The motion of the beaters is a great example of how forces can change the way materials look and feel.

vocabulary.definition: A push or pull that can make something move, stop, or change direction.

hotspots.label: Sugar Bag
hotspots.fact: Sugar is a **solid** — a material that has its own shape and takes up a certain amount of space. When you pour it into a bowl, it stays as tiny grains, even though they spread out. Later, when you add the liquid and mix, the sugar will dissolve, meaning it will break apart into such tiny pieces that you can't see it anymore!

vocabulary.definition: A material that has its own shape and doesn't change unless you do something to it.
